body:
@niketanpansare I finish instruction, test suite.
But my compute report `less memory` error after run a hour for `mvn verify`, so it would be great if some one can launch a jenkins test for this. Or @bertholdreinwald can assign a account for me? :-)

For Instruction, I just leave it there. But may @deroneriksson want add it to http://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/ as a part of instruction for contributor, can address this in another pr.

Regards.
Wenpei.

nice @nakul02 - this is a great feature. Just a couple of comments to streamline this:

1) Layout: Could you please create a more compact output? Something like (a) Spark transfer counts (par, bc, col), (b) Spark transfer times (par, bc, col)
2) Measurement: You should only include the actual buffer pool interactions into this measurements. Please exclude instructions and specific jobs that are anyway measured separately. Also for collect and similar functions please include everything that corresponds to a given matrix as one measurement.
3) Statistic maintenance: Furthermore, please also wrap statistic maintenance into the DmlScript.STATISTIC flag - for very small usecases, stats maintenance itself becomes the bottleneck so we only measure if explicitly requested via -stats.
4) Thread-safeness: Keep in mind that broadcast/collect/parallelize might be called in a multi-threaded parfor context. So please use atomics to prevent anomalies like lost updates.
5) Consistency: For internal consistency, it would be good to remove the Spark class from Statistics and try to integrate your additions similar to existing measurements. Thanks.

@mboehm7  For comment 6, I've updated the logic for isMapWdivmm and added four new tests cases which force replication.  With these changes both WeightedDivMM and WeightedDivMMR can be generated as can be seen by the resulting instructions.  For example:

testWeightedDivMMLeftEpsDenseMRRep
----------  other inst     = MR redwdivmm 0.MATRIX.DOUBLE 3.MATRIX.DOUBLE 5.MATRIX.DOUBLE 0.1.SCALAR.DOUBLE.true 6.MATRIX.DOUBLE DIV_LEFT_EPS false false

testWeightedDivMMLeftEpsDenseMR
----------  mapper inst    = MR mapwdivmm 0.MATRIX.DOUBLE 1.MATRIX.DOUBLE 2.MATRIX.DOUBLE 0.1.SCALAR.DOUBLE.true 3.MATRIX.DOUBLE DIV_LEFT_EPS 

testWeightedDivMMLeftEpsDenseSP
------SPARK mapwdivmm _mVar4.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar5.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar6.MATRIX.DOUBLE 0.1.SCALAR.DOUBLE.true _mVar7.MATRIX.DOUBLE DIV_LEFT_EPS

testWeightedDivMMLeftDenseEpsSPRep
------SPARK redwdivmm _mVar4.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar5.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar6.MATRIX.DOUBLE 0.1.SCALAR.DOUBLE.true _mVar7.MATRIX.DOUBLE DIV_LEFT_EPS false false
Jenkins test this.
test this please.
@lresende I will go ahead and merge this PR then. The location of another LICENSE file may lead to some discussion, so I'll do that in a separate PR.
All tests passed [PR build 184](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/184/).
@shirisht WRT option 1, I renamed the env var to SYSTEMML_STANDALONE_OPTS to attempt to clarify the standalone/singlenode execution. Does that seem clearer? Thank you for reviewing.
Can an Admin verify this patch?

@mboehm7 - couple of questions 

wrt 1) Layout:
Does this look good?
![Changes Highlighted in Red](http://i.imgur.com/4Ooesvc.png?1)

wrt 2) Measurement - 
a) do you mean, I should exclude times counted in by the "Heavy hitter timers"?
b) "please include everything that corresponds to a given matrix as one measurement." - does this also mean all the maps and other higher order functions besides the collect?

wrt 5)Consistency - I think it would make sense to move all spark specific stats into the Spark class, all MR specific stats into the MR class and so on. Right now everything is in this huge monolithic class. thoughts?

Let's put it under ./scripts/staging for now, once we ran sufficient experiments and added required performance features we can put it under algorithms and add necessary documentation. 

Subsequently we can add tests too but we cannot require it given that only a subset of our existing algorithms is included in our test suite. Also, I don't think it's a good idea to replicate all algorithms in Pydml, excepts for selected testcases.

@mboehm7 WRT the existing algorithms, I would think that we probably should have tests for all the primary algorithms already included in the project in the ./scripts directory to validate that they are performing as expected.

ad 1) It goes into the right direction. Try to give it a meaningful name though, something like "Spark transfer times (...)" or "Spark trans times (...)". Also, for consistency, the key separator is ',' not '/'.
ad 2) I mean please exclude, for example, measurements of custom collects in instructions, utils or parfor related features - only focus on the main data transfer - otherwise it would rather confuse than help (e.g., measuring the parallelize of a single header line). Regarding the second aspect, if we collect, for example, an RDD into a single matrix than the entire process including matrix construction needs to be measured and counted as one collect.
ad 5) Well unless there is a good reason for additional complexity, we'll always stick to the simpler solution. So far, I don't see any advantages of this additional nesting since functionality-wise they are equivalent.

If you mean ./scripts/algorithms, then yes I absolutely agree. However, I don't think we should replicate all of them in pydml as it creates maintenance issues. Also, down the road it will become infeasible to have tests for all scripts ever written - so let's be selective here. 

As a higher-level comment, these kinds of tests are also usually not seen as the responsibility of the algorithm writer as the behavior of scripts is not supposed to change. So we cannot really require it but need to add these tests in a best effort manner ourselves.

With regard to replicating scripts in PyDML: I personally think that we should replicate all of our first-tier algorithms in both dialects of the language. There is a substantial community of data scientists that greatly prefers the Python syntax to R syntax. If we do not ship our small set of fully-supported and fully-tested algorithms in both dialects, it sends the wrong message to the Python community.

The larger group of second-tier algorithms with "as-is" support can stay in one dialect.
@deroneriksson please move these kinds of discussions over to the dev list (let's not start them on PRs) and concentrate on the KNN here.

It is just dml script only, i would like to write datagenerate script ,test case and algorithm doc after review script.
But i don't think we will write pydml in future.

Wenpei

@mboehm7 - I've made some changes. 
My initial understanding of measuring time spent in collect(), broadcast() & parallelize() was to measure any invocations.
If I now understand this correctly, then the target is to measure invocations related to operands (matrix blocks). Is this correct?

looks good - just two style comments:
1) could you please simplfy the double negation during lops construction to (!wtype.hasFourInputs() || wtype.hasScalar())
2) also, let's rename qop.hasScalar() to qop.getScalar as it returns a double not a boolean what the name suggests.

@niketanpansare I found build failed in scala doc generate phase (build and test pass). I will do some search today that why automatic doc generated after add scala-maven-plugin:3.2.2 in pom. 
But actually, there are some issues in old code when generate java/scala doc.

I will try to disable automatic doc generate. 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/192/console

well, in general, we want to capture the collect/broadcast/parallelize calls in terms of data transfer between CP and Spark. For now we're only interested in the common case of buffer pool interactions, which means purely the calls in SparkExecutionContext. It would be good to do this in a coarse-grained manner, i.e., measure once for the entire toMatrixBlock including all related overheads, not for individual branches. In more detail:

1) Please fix the statistics output, there is an unnecessary space in the second introduced line, which would be better placed after the colon.
2) Remove the measurements from any parfor-related classes, spark utils, etc and purely focus on the SparkContext
3) Simplify the measurements in SparkExecutionContext, e.g., toMatrixBlock, and  getBroadcastForVar, to have one measurement surrounding all related overheads.
4) Broaden the measurement scope of getJavaRDDHandle to include the block creation not just the actual parallelize.

1) Thread-safeness: Please use Recompiler.recompileProgramBlockHierarchy instead of introducing a new recompileProgramBlocks method into the recompiler. This way you get a thread-safe version of the same functionality (without the danger of concurrent size modifications between DAG recompilations, which could render the control flow reconciliation logic invalid) and you don't need to handle the RecompileStatus.
2) Explain: Could you please enable the explain output for all hops that are flagged as update-in-place, not just DataGen ops - this would give us more debugging opportunities if things go wrong. 
3) Code style: Also, try to avoid unnecessary casts, e.g., write 0L instead of (long)0. It's just easier to read.
@akchinSTC I disable doc generated now, please test again.

Thank you for the review!  I've updated QuaternaryOp, QuaternaryOperator and MatrixBlock.  All tests passed in [PR build 194](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/194/).

@gweidner I do some test today, for scala IDE and eclipse luna
scala IDE:
1. delete project from eclipse
2. run command `mvn eclipse:clean`
3. import mvn project from wizard
4. If face `incompatation issues` , change IDE scala version 
`project->propertiest->scala compiler -> scala installation`
    to Fixed scala Installation: 2.10.5
5. If face `Not found type *` issues. 
  Run command `mvn package`
  And do `project -> refresh`

For eclipse luna:
Except scala IDE pulgin install, please make sure get update from "http://alchim31.free.fr/m2e-scala/update-site" if get `maketplace not found` issues. to update maven connector for scala.

If this works for you, I can add as tips to instruction doc

Thanks Deron, this is very useful. Couple of comments:
1. It would be great to highlight, that the Java application can be built 
   & run with the small footprint system-ml...inmemory.jar
2. Which brings me to the next point that our current pom.xml has 
   commented out building the ...inmemory.jar
3. We need to either document the dependency, or include additional class 
   files, or change the code for missing class files. E.g. using Connection 
   throws a class not found for org/apache/hadoop/conf/Configuration
4. A minor last thing ... you can simplify your DML script. The way you 
   wrote it is some legacy. The compiler does the rewrite automatically but 
   why to write it down like that to start with.
   
   ```
   b = W[numCols+1,] 
   # ones = matrix(1, rows=numRows, cols=1) 
   # Scores = X %*% W[1:numCols,] + ones %*% b;     
   scores = X %*% W[1:numCols,] + b; 
   ```

Regards,
Berthold Reinwald
IBM Almaden Research Center

thanks @asurve - I would just recommend a couple of minor cleanups:
1) Remove the special cases for write (empty frames, replication) and read (ismmfile, localfs) for now
2) Remove schema and names from the write api since the frameblock already carries this information
3) Could you provide overloaded reads for the cases (1) w/ schema and colnames, (2) w/ schema, (3) w/o schema/colnames (if not specified we would assume the schema as string)
great - just one thing: please remove "getSchema( String fname )" from all classes - let's construct a schema of ValueType.STRING according to the number of columns if it is not specified.
LGTM

For reference, below are sample new instructions.

testCrossEntropyEpsDenseCP
CP wcemm _mVar1.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar2.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar3.MATRIX.DOUBLE 0.1.SCALAR.DOUBLE.true _Var4.SCALAR.DOUBLE BASIC_EPS 8

testCrossEntropyEpsDenseMR
mapper inst    = MR mapwcemm 0.MATRIX.DOUBLE 1.MATRIX.DOUBLE 2.MATRIX.DOUBLE 0.1.SCALAR.DOUBLE.true 3.MATRIX.DOUBLE BASIC_EPS

testCrossEntropyEpsDenseMRRep
other inst     = MR redwcemm 0.MATRIX.DOUBLE 3.MATRIX.DOUBLE 5.MATRIX.DOUBLE 0.1.SCALAR.DOUBLE.true 6.MATRIX.DOUBLE BASIC_EPS false false

testCrossEntropyEpsDenseSP
SPARK mapwcemm _mVar4.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar5.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar6.MATRIX.DOUBLE 0.1.SCALAR.DOUBLE.true _Var7.SCALAR.DOUBLE BASIC_EPS

testCrossEntropyEpsDenseSPRep
SPARK redwcemm _mVar4.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar5.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar6.MATRIX.DOUBLE 0.1.SCALAR.DOUBLE.true _Var7.SCALAR.DOUBLE BASIC_EPS false false

For pre-existing pattern (sum(X_log(U%_%t(V)))) where there is no fourth input, default -1.SCALAR.INT.true operand also generated but ignored:
testCrossEntropyDenseCP
CP wcemm _mVar1.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar2.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar3.MATRIX.DOUBLE -1.SCALAR.INT.true _Var4.SCALAR.DOUBLE BASIC 8

In addition to the unit tests, manual testing done to verify matrixMultWCeMMDense, matrixMultWCeMMSparseDense of LibMatrixMult for parallel (e.g., MatrixMultWCeTask where k=8) and single core (k=1).  Also forced matrixMultWCeMMGeneric case via debugger.  Included checks like (_mX==null || !_mX.sparse || scalarX) and (_mX==null || !_mX.sparse || scalarX) in matrixMultWCeMM and MatrixMultWCeTask of LibMatrixMult for consistency.

All unit tests passed in on-demand build against this branch prior to opening PR:
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/116/https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/116/
LGTM.

All tests passed in [PR build 214](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/214/).
Note the branch for this PR includes all commits through March 17.

Thanks @gweidner - it already looks fine. It would be nice though to simplify the runtime a little bit. Since you deal in any case with scalars (eps or 0), I would recommend to compile for type BASIC a 0 instead of the -1 into the instruction, pass it as a scalar double to libmatrixmult, and simplify the internals of libmatrixmult wcemm accordingly.
also thanks for the cleanup of the lops construction of other quaternary operator types.

Thank you @mboehm7 for the review.  I've simplified the scalar processing in LibMatrixMult for wcemm and updated the instruction for BASIC type, e.g., 
CP wcemm _mVar1.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar2.MATRIX.DOUBLE _mVar3.MATRIX.DOUBLE **0.0.SCALAR.DOUBLE.true** _Var4.SCALAR.DOUBLE BASIC 8

The automated PR build 215 is in progress.

LGTM

The test failures of PR build 215 are due to my last commit (tested through eclipse in a shared JVM process which has hidden thread-local initialization issues) - I'll deliver the fix tomorrow morning.

Thanks @arvind. It's too late now but I would have started with the writers as this allows to add separate component tests right away. The current patch has a couple of issues:

1) FrameIndexes/IndexedFrameBlock: please remove these additional data structures as they are plain copies of MatrixIndexes and IndexedMatrixValue and they are not needed for frames.
2) Unnecessary binary read methods: Also, please delete the binary read methods readBinaryBlockBlocksFromHDFS() and readIndexedFrameBlocks() as they are unnecessary.
3) Binary block serialization: Don't use the binary block serialization framework - it will reject frameblocks anyway as they are not supported.
4) ValueType handling: Please remove the custom value type handling from all text readers and use UtilFunctions.stringToObject() instead.
5) FrameBlock copy: It would be good to add some testcases to org.apache.sysml.test.integration.functions.frame for these copy operations. These tests would have shown that the copy cannot work like that: (a) the copy constructor only does a shallow copy of column references, (b) the copy of partial matrix blocks will run into arrayoutofbounds on the column references and also never copies the actual data.
@bertholdreinwald I updated the inmemory.xml file to include several libraries that were required to run the JMLC example. Please let me know if this is how the in-memory jar should be packaged.
